thread.title: Thousands of children's operations - including ones for cancer - cancelled at North East hospitals

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Thousands of children's operations - including ones for cancer - cancelled at North East hospitals

organizations.name: city hospitals sunderland nhs foundation trust

text:
Thousands of children's operations have been cancelled (Image: iStockphoto) Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
North East hospitals have cancelled thousands of children’s operations in recent years.
New figures showed that County Durham and Darlington NHS Foundation Trust has cancelled 5,580 operations for children between 2010-11 and 2018-19.
The trust runs a number of hospitals including University Hospital of North Durham, Darlington Hospital and Bishop Auckland Hospital.
And City Hospitals Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust, which runs Sunderland Royal Hospital, cancelled 3,644 operations in the same period.
The hospital trusts said operations were often cancelled for medical reasons, or to allow more urgent procedures to be carried out.
Figures were obtained by the Labour Party , which submitted freedom of information requests to NHS trusts across the country. Sunderland Royal Hospital (Image: Newcastle Chronicle)
They showed that a record 18,647 emergency and non-emergency children’s operations were cancelled in 2017/18.
Types of operations cancelled include treating broken bones, breast cancer and acute tonsillitis. Read More Newcastle hospitals reveal new measures to help EU staff after Brexit
Operations were cancelled for reasons including equipment failure, staffing shortages and critical care bed unavailability.
Figures for other trusts in the North East were not made available as they did not feature in the five highest for cancellations.
Jonathan Ashworth, Labour’s Shadow Health Secretary, called on Chancellor Philip Hammond to provide the NHS with more funding, when the Chancellor delivers his Budget statemen t, an annual statement about the nation’s finances, on Monday.
He said: “The cancellation of an operation brings tremendous anguish and uncertainty which must be especially unsettling for children and their families. Chancellor Philip Hammond leaves number 11 Downing Street (Image: Getty Images Europe)
"Behind each of these cancellations is a sick child and their loved ones facing unnecessary distress for entirely avoidable reasons. Read More The heartwarming reason these inspirational women are tackling a charity trek in India
“These cancelled operations risk harming children further in the long term and it’s shameful that cancellations have reached this level.
“The fact that thousands of children’s operations – including for broken bones, removing rotten teeth, eye surgery and even breast cancer – have had to be cancelled on this scale reveals yet again an NHS pushed to the brink by the Tories.” Read More Newcastle MP piles pressure on NUFC owner Mike Ashley
The Government says it is putting that extra funding into the national health service, to reach £20bn a year in real terms by 2023-24.
A spokesperson for County Durham & Darlington NHS Foundation Trust said: “These figures include all surgical procedures for patients under the age of 18, which are cancelled once an appointment has been made. NHS staff (Image: PA)
“We work hard to avoid having to rearrange appointments which can be for a number of reasons, including the family choosing not to accept the appointment or being unable to attend. This accounts for a third of these cancellations. Read More Teenager fighting for his life and another, 17, seriously injured in Friday night crash on A189 in Northumberland
“At University Hospital of North Durham and Darlington Memorial Hospital we also perform emergency procedures which can, on occasion lead to the cancellation of less urgent planned surgeries.
“If a cancellation is necessary we understand the distress and inconvenience this can cause and work closely with families to explain, and plan a new appointment.” Read More
